item.title: Macron Agrees to Coordinate Approach on Iran With Putin
item.description: French President Emmanuel Macron and his Russian counterpart Vladimir Putin agreed to coordinate their approach on Iran in a phone call on Tuesday that lasted for more than two hours.
item.dc:creator: Samy Adghirni

media:content.media:description: French President Emmanuel Macron. Photographer: Benoit Tessier/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Trump’s Tax Bill Passes US Senate as Republicans Notch Major Win
item.description: Donald Trump’s $3.3 trillion tax and spending cut bill passed the Senate Tuesday after a furious push by Republican leaders to persuade holdouts to back the legislation and hand the president a political win.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Steven T. Dennis, Emily Birnbaum

media:content.media:description: The US Capitol in Washington, DC. Photographer: Graeme Sloan/Bloomberg

item.title: Mamdani Seals NYC Mayoral Primary, Extending Lead Over Cuomo
item.description: Upstart democratic socialist Zohran Mamdani clinched the Democratic nomination for mayor of New York City, extending his lead to 12 points in the primary over Andrew Cuomo and raising new doubts about the viability of the former governor running as a third-party candidate.
item.dc:creator: Gregory Korte, Laura Nahmias

media:content.media:description: Zohran Mamdani at a campaign event on June 23

item.title: Putin Offers Special Account to Lure New Investors to Russia
item.description: President Vladimir Putin signed a decree in an attempt to attract new foreign investment into Russia’s financial markets, despite sweeping sanctions over the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Kira Zavyalova

media:content.media:description: Vladimir Putin Photographer: Alexander Nemenov/Getty Images

item.title: Starmer’s Welfare Overhaul Hangs in Balance Ahead of Vote
item.description: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer is girding for what could be the most consequential vote of his premiership, with dozens of Labour rebels expecting to vote against the government’s welfare overhaul despite huge concessions to push it through parliament.
item.dc:creator: Lucy White, Ailbhe Rea

media:content.media:description: Keir Starmer Source: UK Parliament

item.title: NOAA Budget Cuts to Gut Climate and Ocean Research, Slash Jobs
item.description: The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration is proposing cutting about 18% of its workforce and slashing $1.5 billion from its budget, including terminating programs to protect coastal communities and research that supports better forecasts and natural disaster prediction.
item.dc:creator: Brian K Sullivan, Lou Del Bello

media:content.media:description: A tropical analysis meteorologist at his station at the NOAA research center in Miami.

item.title: Senators to Vote on Trump’s Tax Bill After Deal, Thune Says
item.description: Senate Majority Leader John Thune said his chamber will soon vote on passage of President Donald Trump’s tax and spending bill after securing enough support to pass the legislation.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Emily Birnbaum, Steven T. Dennis

media:content.media:description: Senator Lisa Murkowski

item.title: Lula Appeals to Brazil Supreme Court to Uphold Tax Hike Plan
item.description: Brazil’s government will appeal to the Supreme Court to try to save a controversial tax decree overturned by Congress, escalating a fight between President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva and lawmakers over the administration’s efforts to shore up its budget.
item.dc:creator: Martha Viotti Beck

media:content.media:description: Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva

item.title: Turkey Cracks Down on Magazine Over Alleged Prophet Cartoon
item.description: Turkey detained four employees of a satirical magazine including a cartoonist accused of depicting the Prophet Muhammad, as the government intensifies its crackdown on dissent.
item.dc:creator: Ugur Yilmaz

media:content.media:description: Protesters shout slogans against cartoonists as they gather outside LeMan’s office in Istanbul on June 30.

item.title: Russia Hands Ex-Deputy Defense Minister 13 Years for Graft
item.description: A Russian court sentenced a former deputy defense minister to 13 years in prison on embezzlement charges, the Tass news service reported, the highest ranking military official to be convicted since President Vladimir Putin appointed a new head of the Defense Ministry last year.
item.dc:creator: Henry Meyer

media:content.media:description: Timur Ivanov at Moscow City Court on July 1. Photographer: Alexander Nemenov/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: EU to Accept Trump Universal Tariff But Seeks Key Exemptions
item.description: The European Union is willing to accept a trade arrangement with the US that includes a 10% universal tariff on many of the bloc’s exports, but wants the US to commit to lower rates than that on key sectors such as pharmaceuticals, alcohol, semiconductors and commercial aircraft.
item.dc:creator: Jorge Valero, Alberto Nardelli

item.title: Russia's Crude Oil Shipments Stick Close to a Two-Month Low
item.description: Lower exports from smaller ports offset increased flows from two key terminals
item.dc:creator: Julian Lee

media:content.media:description: Oil and LNG tanker vessels offshore from the Fort de Bouc in the industrial and port area of Martigues, France, on Monday, Jan. 6, 2023. The European Union on Sunday ratcheted up its sanctions against President Vladimir Putin's regime, putting in place a long-planned ban on seaborne imports of Russian fuels.

item.title: Trump-Musk Battle Restarts After Billionaire Bashes Tax Bill
item.description: Donald Trump threatened to withdraw government subsidies from Elon Musk’s companies and examine the billionaire’s immigration status after the Tesla Inc. chief executive officer ratcheted up his criticism of the president’s tax and spending bill.
item.dc:creator: Jasmine Ng

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump and Elon Musk walk past a Tesla Model S on the South Lawn of the White House on March 11.

item.title: Florida Taps Contractors With No Detention Experience for ‘Alligator Alcatraz’
item.description: On June 20, nearly three weeks into the Atlantic hurricane season, Florida disaster-management officials assembled a group of emergency relief contractors in Tallahassee and asked them to do something they had never done before.
item.dc:creator: Michael Smith, Sophie Alexander, Rachel Adams-Heard

media:content.media:description: Generators are driven into Dade Collier Training and Transition Airport in Ochopee, Florida.

item.title: Iran Shuts Out Nuclear Monitors in Tactics Echoing Cold War
item.description: Iran is said to be cutting off communication with key United Nations watchdog officials, deepening uncertainty over the status of its nuclear program and introducing additional ambiguity to the diplomatic showdown with Washington.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Tirone

item.title: Musk Walks Back Chainsaw Wielding Display: ‘It Lacked Empathy’
item.description: Elon Musk is expressing some regret for waving a chainsaw to rile up the crowd during a conservative conference back in February, as his feud with Donald Trump over the president’s tax and spending bill reignites.
item.dc:creator: Aysha Diallo

media:content.media:description: CEO of Tesla Elon Musk holds a chainsaw alongside Argentine President Javier Milei during the 2025 CPAC in Oxon Hill, Maryland, on Feb. 20.

item.title: Ukraine Says Its Drones Hit Russian Anti-Aircraft Missile Plant
item.description: Ukraine said its long-range drones hit a military plant on Tuesday that produces anti-aircraft systems in the Russian city of Izhevsk.
item.dc:creator: Olesia Safronova

media:content.media:description: The Kupol facility in Russia’s Udmurtia Republic in the Volga region.

item.title: Trump Says He’ll Have to ‘Take a Look’ at Deporting Musk
item.description: President Donald Trump said he would look into deporting billionaire Elon Musk in response to a question about the ally-turned-critic of his signature tax and spending legislation.
item.dc:creator: Skylar Woodhouse, Akayla Gardner

media:content.media:description: Elon Musk and Donald Trump Photographer: Nathan Laine/Bloomberg, Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images

item.title: Senate Pulls All-Nighter on Trump Tax Bill With GOP Divided
item.description: Senate Republican leaders continue to scrounge for votes to pass Donald Trump’s $3.3 trillion tax and spending bill as lingering intraparty fights threaten to upend the legislative centerpiece of the president’s domestic agenda.
item.dc:creator: Steven T. Dennis, Erik Wasson, Jennifer A Dlouhy

media:content.media:description: Senator Joni Ernst

item.title: Turkey Considers Raising Cap on Loan Growth in Early Easing Sign
item.description: Turkey is discussing loosening limits on some commercial loans, according to people familiar with the matter, signaling policymakers are comfortable starting to ease financing conditions.
item.dc:creator: Beril Akman, Firat Kozok

media:content.media:description: Pedestrians near the Yeni Camii mosque in Istanbul, Turkey. Photographer: Kerem Uzel/Bloomberg

item.title: Bessent Says US Hopes to See China Magnets Flow at ‘Faster Rate’
item.description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said the US is hopeful China will do more to ease the export of rare earth magnets after last month’s deal between the two countries, saying flows had still not returned to levels seen in early April.
item.dc:creator: Akayla Gardner

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent, US treasury secretary, during a Bloomberg Television interview in New York, US, on Monday, June 30, 2025. Bessent indicated it wouldn’t make sense for the government to ramp up sales of longer-term securities given where yields are today, though he held out hope that interest rates across maturities will be falling as inflation slows.

item.title: NYC Passes $116 Billion Budget as Mayor Adams Looks to Election
item.description: New York City Mayor Eric Adams reached a deal with the City Council on a $115.9 billion budget, adding new funding for legal services for migrants and more money for early childhood education.
item.dc:creator: Laura Nahmias

media:content.media:description: Eric Adams (center) is running for reelection as an independent.

item.title: Poland to Impose Checks at German Border Amid Migration Furore
item.description: Poland’s government will impose temporary border checks with Germany in an escalating row over irregular migration between the European Union neighbors.
item.dc:creator: Konrad Krasuski

media:content.media:description: A Polish border marker in Slubice, Poland.

item.title: Josh Kraft Helped by Dad, Rich Pals in Bid to Oust Boston Mayor
item.description: Josh Kraft is a political novice seeking to become the first person in 76 years to unseat an incumbent mayor in Boston — and a popular one at that. Yet the money is flowing in.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ryan

media:content.media:description: Mayoral candidate Josh Kraft speaks at a press conference in Boston on June 2.

item.title: Senate Votes 99-1 to Strip AI Provision From Trump’s Tax Bill
item.description: The Senate killed a controversial effort to prevent US states from regulating artificial intelligence, marking a loss for the Silicon Valley leaders and White House officials who pushed the measure.

media:content.media:description: Tennessee Senator Marsha Blackburn at the US Capitol on June 30. Photographer: Francis Chung/Politico/AP Photo

item.title: Thailand Plunges Deeper Into Crisis as Court Suspends Leader
item.description: Thailand’s Constitutional Court suspended Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra from office until it rules on a petition seeking her permanent removal over alleged ethical misconduct, deepening a crisis that threatens to end her family’s over two-decade dominance of the country’s politics.
item.dc:creator: Patpicha Tanakasempipat

media:content.media:description: Paetongtarn Shinawatra speaks to the media in Bangkok on July 1. Photographer: Valeria Mongelli/Bloomberg

item.title: China Sanctions Former Philippine Senator as Tensions Swell

item.title: Trump Lifts Syria Sanctions in Bid to Boost New Government
item.description: President Donald Trump signed an executive order terminating American sanctions on Syria, aiming to boost the Arab nation’s battered economy and support the new government after rebels overthrew the regime of Bashar Al-Assad last year.
item.dc:creator: Eric Martin

media:content.media:description: People celebrate in Damascus' Omeyyad square after US President Donald Trump's decision to lift sanctions in Syria, on May 13.
